div.div:
And the following cavalrymen were dispatched together by the
People of the Athenians to escort
the Pythais.1

Cavalry commander:
Diokles son of Diokles2
Tribal cavalry commanders:
ErechtheisI
Hagias son of Boulon3
AigeisII
Hermon son of Antiphon.4

div.p:
!+1+Textual Note AIO accepts the restoration of Ε[ὐμαρεί]δης in col. 1, l. 14 by H. Pomtow in Syll.3 697g.
This list of 63 cavalrymen from the second Pythais at Delphi, which took place in 128/7 BC, was inscribed on the southern façade of the Athenian Treasury, occupying a rectangular space on two blocks one on top of the other (join at l. 22). On the Pythais and the Treasury, see F.Delphes III 2, 3 and on Attic inscriptions at Delphi, see IG II3 4, 17 with notes. Cavalrymen rode alongside the procession as escorts and participated in contests during the Pythais, see S. Kühn, Pythais-Prozession, 2018, 156 and F.Delphes III 2, 34–42. A similar roster of participating cavalrymen survives from the third Pythais (F.Delphes III 2, 28); the cavalrymen of the fourth Pythais were listed as part of the roster of ephebes (F.Delphes III 2, 26). Unlike other lists from the second Pythais, this cavalry list does not have a spatial connection with the other cavalry list on the Treasury (F.Delphes III 2, 28), but is located directly beneath a Delphic honorific decree for the association (koinon) of cavalrymen in Athens and key cavalry commanders (F.Delphes III 2, 46, also in 128/7 BC), to which it is linked by the opening ‘and’: it suggests that this list presents the members of this association, including those who did not necessarily participate in the second Pythais. The heading takes two and a half lines (ll. 1-3), leaving space on the right side of the line. The first line of col. 2 starts at l. 3.!
!+2+ Diokles son of Diokles is also mentioned in F.Delphes III 2, 24, l. 5 (from the same Pythais), where he holds the title '(general) of the cavalry' (epi to hippikon), while here and in F.Delphes III 2, 46, l. 9 he is 'commander of the cavalry' (hipparchos). On the difference of his titles, see F.Delphes III 2, 24 with notes.!
!+3+ Thanks to their participation in the contests for the Pythais, as well as family relationships with other Pythaists, we can identify some names in this lists despite the lack of patronyms and demonyms. Hagias (col. 1, l. 7), Hermon (l. 10), Pyrrhos (l. 16), Byttakos (l. 17), Charinos(l. 27), Zoilos (l. 28), Sotion (l. 29), Kallitheos(l. 39), and Kallistratos (col. 2, l. 35) are attested in F.Delphes III 2, 34-42 as victors in the cavalry contests of the second Pythais.!
!+4+ In F.Delphes III 2, 24, four tribal cavalry commanders are mentioned without tribal filiation. Here the tribes of two tribal cavalry commanders are specified, and the other two tribal cavalry commanders are not mentioned. On tribal cavalry commanders and their duties, see IG II3 1, 949 with note. The biological father of Hermon, Antiphon, was added inline in F.Delphes III 2, 24, l. 6, but here he is directly mentioned as son of Antiphon.!
!+5+ On Eumareides, an ephebe in the first Pythais (F.Delphes III 2, 23, col. 2, l. 21), see IG II3 4, 368. Others who had been Pythaists before include Polykleitos (col. 1, l. 37, Pythaist-boy in 138/7, F.Delphes III 2, 11, l. 10), Amyntas (col. 2, l. 3, ephebe in 138/7, F.Delphes III 2, 23, col. 2, l. 9), and Rhadamanthys (see below).!
!+6+ Alkidamos (col. 1, l. 15) was honoured by the Delphians in this year for bringing a tripod on a chariot during the procession back to Athens in F.Delphes III 2, 33. This ritual of bringing the tripod on a chariot was also mentioned in F.Delphes III 2, 32 (from the fourth Pythais). See S. Kühn, Pythais-Prozession, 2018, 128-130.!
!+7+ Eudemos (col. 2, l. 14) and Rhadamanthys (col. 2, l. 28) appear also in the list of official visitors (theōroi), F.Delphes III 2, 8. A possible explanation is that they were honoured because of their status as cavalrymen, but they served as theōroi in this Pythais and did not join the group of cavalrymen in the procession. Other people serving as other roles but mentioned here include: Mnesitheos (col. 1, l. 36, also as court president in F.Delphes III 2, 3, col. 1, l. 10), Theophrastos (col. 2, l. 11, also as hoplite general in F.Delphes III 2, 24, ll. 3–4), Glaukos (col. 2, l. 18, also as Polemarch in F.Delphes III 2, 3, col. 1, l. 5), Hipparchos (col. 2, l. 21, perhaps also as general of the fleet in F.Delphes III 2, 24, l. 4)!
!+8+ The word 'theōros' (col. 2, l. 20) was centred, like the tribal rubrics. If this word is interpreted as the title, ‘official visitor’ (per G. Colin in F.Delphes III 2, 27, p. 34), one needs to explain why Hipparchos was added to this list and not to the list of F.Delphes III 2, 8. Alternatively, it might be a personal name (perhaps a relative of Theoros son of Theoros who was an ephebe in 97/6 BC, cf. F.Delphes III 2, 26, col. 2, l. 7, as has been argued by Pomtow in Syll.3, Tracy, BCH 99, 1975, 192–93, and Rutherford, State Pilgrims, 2014, 164), with the ambiguity of the word as title or personal name leading the stonecutter to make an understandable mistake. It is more likely that this Hipparchos (l. 21) is identical to Hipparchos of Piraeus, who served as the general of the fleet this year as mentioned in F.Delphes III 2, 24, l. 4 and would become the manager (epimelētes) of Delos in 114/3 BC (I Délos 1901).!
!+9+ The names of the cavalrymen are listed by tribe, but the name of the twelfth tribe, Attalis, is omitted. Menophilos is named as a cavalryman of Attalis in 106/5 BC (F.Delphes III 2, 28, col. 3, l. 30), and thus at least the last five cavalrymen (col. 2, ll. 37-41) should come from Attalis (Pomtow in Syll.2; Sundwall, Nachträge zur Prosopographia Attica, 1910, 128). S. Tracy, BCH 99, 1975, 193 supposes that, given that Attalis had 11 cavalrymen and Antiochis only 7 in the third Pythais of 106/5 BC, 'something more than half of the 16 cavalrymen listed here under Antiochis in fact belonged to Attalis.' However, the fact that Kekropis, which had only four cavalrymen in 128/7 BC, had twelve representatives in 106/5 BC, challenges this suggestion.!
